list_page_teaser: What type of person could come up with this idea, of writing a program that draws people's personalities?  See for yourself by checking out a few of my Self-Portraits!
description_html:
These are spiritual portraits of yours truly, Tom W. Hartung, the creator of this site!

These portraits may look a little bit different from each other, but all of them have the same overall mood. This is because they all show a fairly strong preference for being idealism (iNtuition, represented by the Blue) over pragmatism (Sensation, represented by the Yellow).

The images here also all show relatively mild preferences for the Feeling-Thinking and the Judging-Perceiving pairs of opposites. This balance makes all of the images fairly colorful, showing I am versatile and flexible.

These spiritual portraits also demonstrate how the Groja © program can draw higher-resolution images that can be quite intricate, but still convey the same overall mood.
story_html:
My results on the Keirsey questionnaire show a very slight preference for Feeling (Red) over Thinking (Green). My results on the Humanmetrics questionairre show the opposite: a very slight preference for Thinking (Green) over Feeling (Red).

My results on the Keirsey questionnaire show a very slight preference for Perceiving (increasing the amount Blue and Yellow) over Judging (increasing the amount of Green and Red). My results on the Real MBTI ® questionairre show the opposite: a very slight preference for Judging (Green and Red) over Perceiving (Blue and Yellow).

An INFP with a stronger Feeling preference is Woody Allen. I find it fairly easy to relate to him, but defintely feel more logical (Woody did not like school, but I loved it).

An INTJ with a stronger Thinking preference is the fictional character from True Detective, Rust Cohle. I find it easier to relate to his character than to most cops, but definitely feel that he's much more extreme than I could ever be.

I feel strongly that my awareness of these differences — even these more subtle differences which are more of degree rather than just type — is very helpful in my day-to-day life. I consider this site, and the vision it presents, to be my very own personal equivalent of Sailor's snakeskin jacket.

For more, see my article on medium.com about all this!

image_list.title: Tom H. I
image_list.subtitle_html: Results of the Keirsey Temperament Sorter, 1987
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: This spiritual portrait is based on the results of one of the first times I answered Keirsey's questionnaire.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this image represents my very slight preference for using emotion rather than logic to make decisions.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  Looking at the score scales, you can see that this is a very slight preference, allowing me to adapt and use logic when the situation calls for it.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this image represents my preference for ideas over facts.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Compared to the other pairs of opposites, this is a fairly strong preference and shows up consistently when I take different versions of the various four-letter-type online quizzes.
image_list.story_html:
This image is based on a score from one of the first times I took the Keirsey Temperament Sorter. Like others I have talked to, at first I was surprised to learn I was an INFP!

I have actually taken various versions of the quiz – this is kind of a hobby of mine – and have even written my own!.

Because this is my first self-portrait, it holds a special signifigance for me and is my favorite.
